channel.title: Change DNS record on server
channel.description:
If I have an A record for * set to 64.191.203.36, this will make all subdomains of my domain point to my server.
Is there a way for the server to specify a different A record when the user sends a request to this IP address, or at least route the request elsewhere without proxying?
Example, User sends a request to mail.digg.com (Let's say this is my server) This address resolves to the IP 64.191.203.36 (Still my server) The server sends a response back to the server saying the IP is actually 209.85.229.109 (GMail server) User sends email to gmail-smtp-msa.l.google.com

item.title: Change DNS record on server
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

Yeah, you are right about @ and *, my apologies.

It sounds like you just want to use your own server for DNS requests, which is essentially pointless tbh because you have the ability to add records anyway.
Are you doing some kind of redirect service (possibly dynamic/whatever)? That is best left to whatever HTTP server you are running, for example in lighttpd:

given *.foo.com -> your server:

$HTTP["host"] == "bar.foo.com" { server.document-root = "/var/www/bar/" # use /var/www/bar as document root for bar.foo.com } $HTTP["host"] == "baz.foo.com" { url.redirect = ( ".*" => "http://goatse.ca/", # maybe you want to redirect everything to goatse "^/(.*)" => "http://herp.org/derp/$1 # or redirect any page access to herp.org/derp/<page> }

I am still not sure what you are after, not very clear.

Read full topic

item.title: Change DNS record on server
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“c|p, post:4, topic:333765”]If you are just asking about email forwarding, you should look into using google apps.
Pretty straightforward setup, and some registrars have an automagic feature to fill in mail records for google apps.

If you are asking about having a wildcard A record while still having known A records, just set them accordingly, eg:

foo.bar.com A 12.34.56.78 baz.bar.com A 78.56.34.12 @.bar.com A 51.25.51.51

where @ is a wildcard record (for most registrars anyway).[/quote]
I probably didn’t describe what I want to do very well…

I don’t want to forward email, I want to forward any type of request to a server to another server. My example happened to be for a mail server, but it could be for anything such as SSH or FTP.

Also, on my registra it uses * as a wildcard, and @ simply indicates a record for the base address (google.com as opposed to www.google.com). I’d want every subdomain of the domain pointing to my server so the server can then decide where the subdomain should point to.
